div1.p: [Carter] describes Henry Rose Carter's efforts to complete his book on yellow fever despite suffering continued illness.

div1.head: Script for a talk, by [Laura Armistead Carter], November 2, 1931
div1.p: 11/2/31 Talk for XIXth Century Club p.1

On the day of his return from Peru (where, as Sanitary Advisor of
the Peruvian Government, he had just stamped out an epidemic of yellow
fever in the northern part of that country) Father was asked, by the Rocke-
feller Foundation to write a history of yellow fever. His health was much
broken and he replied that he would almost certainly die before the completion
of such a work Realizing its importance, however, he added that if he found
he could plan the book in sections. “like a flight of steps,” each subdivision
being a complete in itselfentity, though correlated with whatthe others so that whoever came after him could go on from
where he left off, he would undertake the work. He was able to spo plan
the book and began work shortly thereafter (early in 1922). After several
severe attacks of angina, the following summer, he realized that he would
have even less time to give to the work than he had anticipated. He there-
fore devoted all his efforts to finishing during his lifetime a section
which should be complete in itself--the early history of yellow fever. That
is the book which here presented to you. Even this was completed only by
working throughout long illnesses, the last year of his life he was being 2 con-
tinuously confined to his bed. Yet knowing that any of the frequent inter-
ruptions to his work might be the finallast one, in constant discomfort, in al-
most constant pain his energy and enthusiamm were unabated and he worked on,
dictating towards the lastend (when too weak to write) until within five hours
of the beginning of his last illness. And he had the final satisfaction of
knowing that hsis race against time was won! By a narrow margin, it is true,
and with some legacies of further work to others, before the book, as he had
planned it could be given to the world. However, that part of the work which
no one but he could have done he did! It was signifigcant of the spirit of
in which the book was written and of the appreciateion of the fact by others,
that when the news of his last illness became known, out of the stream of
messages that poured in from his confrères in all parts of the world, all
sent congratulations that he had reached his goaell! There was not Not one man sent a
